option.name: title_text
option.value: Enhancing Online Course Engagement through Interactive Formative Assessment.

string_table.name: npxabnsnfns10111111101
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidelink.displaytext: Why are Interactive Formative Assessments Important for Online Classes?

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Guidelines for Online Assessments for Educators

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Hi, I heard you were interested in increasing interactivity in your online classes using formative assessments. I have some ideas for you for both asynchronous and synchronous classes. First, we’ll explore options for a synchronous class." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Now that we’ve covered some of the many options available for synchronous classes and asynchronous classes , let’s think about what they have in common with each other." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When you are ready, click NEXT like always. You should click on boxes next to the attributes that interactive formative assessments have in common with each other. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You’ll be receiving five questions, all of which will require slightly different ways of responding, so be sure to read the directions. The entire summative assessment should take less than 5 minutes to complete." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Thank you for taking the course. If you have any questions or suggestions, please contact me via email dave.hochstein@wright.edu" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: Formative assessments are generally low-stakes assessment practices that allow instructors to monitor student understanding. They provide ongoing feedback allowing instructors to improve their instruction and students to improve their understanding.

Retreival practice is a method of increasing memory through assessments requring the student to pull information from memory. This allows the student to know what they do and do not know, as well as providing practice in the retreival of that particular information.
Social presence is the extent to which students can identify, communicate, and develop relationships within a course. (Garrison, 2016)
Sumative assessments are generally high-stakes assessment practices that provide instructors a measure of how much the student has learned at the end of an instructional unit.
Teaching prescence is the extent to which there is leadership that provides for the design, facilitation, and direction of the educational expereince (Garrison, 2016).
